overview: This measure appropriates funds for the Judiciary for the fiscal biennium beginning July 1, 2025, and ending June 30, 2027. [8] Operating resource requests focus on making permanent or expanding three Specialty Courts on O‘ahu, staffing the new Wahiawā District Court, adding a District Court Judge in Kona, funding cybersecurity, supporting the Criminal Justice Research Institute (CJRI), and restoring essential staff funding. [7] The bill has been amended to include additional funding for civil and immigration-related legal services. [9] [9]
appropriations: The Judiciary requests additional operating resources amounting to $6.17M in FY 2026 and $6.25M in FY 2027. [7] The Senate Committee on Judiciary amended the measure to increase the appropriation for Administration (JUD601) by $1,750,000 (HB400_SD1_SSCR1253_.htm.txt), which includes an additional $1,000,000 (HB400_SD1_SSCR1253_.htm.txt) for civil legal services and $750,000 (HB400_SD1_SSCR1253_.htm.txt) for legal services to individuals in immigration-related court proceedings. [9] [9] The bill also authorizes general obligation bonds not to exceed $11,900,000 (HB400_SD1_.HTM.txt) for capital improvement projects. [8]
assumptions_and_methodology: The Judiciary's budget request is based on current circumstances and projected resource needs for the future. [7] Cost estimations include funding to make pilot programs permanent, such as the Women’s Court Pilot Project, which is set to expire at the end of FY 2025. [7] The methodology also incorporates costs to fully staff new facilities like the Wahiawā District Court, which will open in Spring 2026, and to restore funding for positions defunded during the COVID-19 pandemic. [7] [7]
agency_impact: The appropriations will allow the Judiciary to establish a permanent Women’s Court with 8.0 FTE permanent positions. [7] It will also significantly expand the Truancy Court and EEIP on O‘ahu and make the DWI Court Program permanent. [7] [7] The funding will also support staffing for the new Wahiawā District Court, add a District Court Judge in Kona to address an extraordinary caseload, and fund a dedicated cybersecurity staff. [7] [7] [7]
economic_impact: The Women's Court program aims to aid participants in bettering their economic conditions and life circumstances. [7] Funding for civil legal services addresses problems associated with eviction, homelessness, deportation, and family separation, reducing the likelihood of greater future costs. [7] Testimony from The Legal Clinic notes an increased demand for pro bono legal immigration services due to federal immigration enforcement actions. [7]
policy_impact: This measure transitions the Women’s Court Pilot Project, established in 2022, into a permanent program. [7] It also secures permanent funding for the DWI Court Program, which has been operational since 2013. [7] The measure also provides additional funding for civil legal services and legal services for individuals in immigration-related court proceedings in response to federal actions. [9] [9]
revenue_sources: The measure authorizes the issuance of general obligation bonds, not to exceed $11,900,000 (HB400_SD1_.HTM.txt), to finance capital improvement projects. [8] The Judiciary's operating budget requests, including the added funds for legal services, will be supported by general funds (MOF A). [8] [9] Third-party testimony requested an increase of an additional $1,000,000 (HB400_HD1_TESTIMONY_JDC_03-19-25_.PDF.txt) for the civil legal services line item. [7]
six_year_fiscal_implications: The Judiciary requests additional operating resources of $6.17M in FY 2026 and $6.25M in FY 2027. [7] The request for the Women’s Court is $705,416 (HB400_HD1_TESTIMONY_JDC_03-19-25_.PDF.txt) in FY 2026 and $705,416 (HB400_HD1_TESTIMONY_JDC_03-19-25_.PDF.txt) in FY 2027. [7] For the Truancy Court and EEIP, the request is $188,388 (HB400_HD1_TESTIMONY_JDC_03-19-25_.PDF.txt) in FY 2026 and $183,288 (HB400_HD1_TESTIMONY_JDC_03-19-25_.PDF.txt) in FY 2027. [7] The DWI Court Program requests $232,412 (HB400_HD1_TESTIMONY_JDC_03-19-25_.PDF.txt) in FY 2026 and $237,612 (HB400_HD1_TESTIMONY_JDC_03-19-25_.PDF.txt) in FY 2027. [7] Staffing the Wahiawā District Court includes restoring funding of $192,408 (HB400_HD1_TESTIMONY_JDC_03-19-25_.PDF.txt) in FY 2026 and $192,408 (HB400_HD1_TESTIMONY_JDC_03-19-25_.PDF.txt) in FY 2027 for adult client services. [7] [7] The request for a Kona District Court Judge and staff is $368,943 (HB400_HD1_TESTIMONY_JDC_03-19-25_.PDF.txt) in FY 2026 and $360,048 (HB400_HD1_TESTIMONY_JDC_03-19-25_.PDF.txt) in FY 2027. [7] Cybersecurity upgrades are requested at $1,175,300 (HB400_HD1_TESTIMONY_JDC_03-19-25_.PDF.txt) for FY 2026 and $1,175,300 (HB400_HD1_TESTIMONY_JDC_03-19-25_.PDF.txt) in FY 2027. [7] [7] A request for the Criminal Justice Research Institute is $512,624 (HB400_HD1_TESTIMONY_JDC_03-19-25_.PDF.txt) in FY 2026 and $577,058 (HB400_HD1_TESTIMONY_JDC_03-19-25_.PDF.txt) in FY 2027. [7] The Committee on Judiciary recommends increasing the appropriation for Administration by $1,750,000 (HB400_SD1_SSCR1253_.htm.txt) for legal services for the biennium. [9] Making these programs and positions permanent will create recurring costs beyond the 2025-2027 biennium. [7]
operating_revenue_impact: The provided documents do not indicate any anticipated impacts on operating revenues as a result of this measure. [7]
capital_expenditure_impact: The Judiciary requests a total of $11.9M (HB400_HD1_TESTIMONY_JDC_03-19-25_.PDF.txt) in CIP bond funds for FY 2026. [7] Specific requests include $4.0 million (HB400_HD1_TESTIMONY_JDC_03-19-25_.PDF.txt) to design a new South Kohala District Courthouse, $900,000 (HB400_HD1_TESTIMONY_JDC_03-19-25_.PDF.txt) to replace an A/C chiller on Kaua‘i, and $7.0 million (HB400_HD1_TESTIMONY_JDC_03-19-25_.PDF.txt) in lump sum bond funds for statewide facility improvements. [7] [7] [7] This lump sum includes $2.0 million (HB400_HD1_TESTIMONY_JDC_03-19-25_.PDF.txt) to address a funding shortfall for the relocation of the Children’s Justice Center on Oʻahu. [7]
fiscal_implications_after_6_years: Making the Women's Court and DWI Court Program permanent will create ongoing operational costs beyond the initial biennium. [7] [7] Restoring funding for essential staff positions will also result in recurring expenses in future fiscal years. [7] The added funding for legal services may also become a recurring request to meet community needs. [9]
updates_from_previous_fiscal_note: The Senate Committee on Judiciary has amended this measure by increasing the appropriation for Administration (JUD601) by $1,750,000 (HB400_SD1_SSCR1253_.htm.txt). [9] This increase provides an additional $1,000,000 (HB400_SD1_SSCR1253_.htm.txt) for civil legal services and $750,000 (HB400_SD1_SSCR1253_.htm.txt) for legal services to individuals in immigration-related court proceedings. [9] The effective date has been changed from July 1, 3000 to April 23, 2057, to facilitate further discussion. [9]
fte_positions: The Judiciary requests additional operating resources for 17.0 permanent FTE and 1.0 temporary FTE. [7] The request to establish a permanent Women's Court includes 8.0 FTE permanent positions, representing a net increase of one. [7] [7] Other requests include 4.0 FTE permanent positions for an additional Kona District Court Judge and support staff, and 3.0 FTE permanent positions for Social Services Assistants for the Office of the Public Guardian. [7] [7]
appropriations_changes: This version of the bill includes a new appropriation for legal services that was not in the previous version. [9] The Senate Committee on Judiciary amended the measure by increasing the appropriation for Administration (JUD601) by $1,750,000 (HB400_SD1_SSCR1253_.htm.txt). [9] The bill now contains placeholder sections to expend unspecified sums for civil legal services and for legal services in immigration-related proceedings. [8] [8]
funding_sources_changes: The funding source for the new appropriations for civil and immigration-related legal services is the general fund (MOF A). [8] [9] This is reflected as an increase to the general fund appropriation for the Administration (JUD601) program. [9] The funding source for capital improvement projects remains general obligation bonds. [8]
department_impact: There have been no changes in departmental responsibility; all appropriations are for the Judiciary. [8]
reports_required: The provided documents do not identify any new or modified reporting requirements for the Judiciary. [7]
pilot_program: The Women’s Court Pilot Project was established by the Legislature in July of 2022 with funding for a three-year pilot. [7] This bill requests funding to establish a permanent Women’s Court as the pilot is set to expire at the end of FY 2025. [7] The DWI Court Program, established in 2012, has been operational with federal grant funding, and this bill seeks to make the program permanent. [7]
sunset_date: The seven temporary positions for the Women’s Court Pilot Project are set to expire at the end of FY 2025. [7] Funding for one permanent and one temporary Project Specialist position for the Criminal Justice Research Institute (CJRI) ends on June 30, 2025. [7] [7]
effective_date: The Senate Committee on Judiciary amended this measure by changing the effective date to April 23, 2057, to facilitate further discussion. [9] This replaces the previous defective effective date of July 1, 3000. [7]
